concern:
Hi! First post on this sub, and it’s such a crazy story.

This last semester (1st year, out of state) I was rooming with one of my good friends, at a small private university. 

We walk into our dorm together and bam, a single queen sized bed in a room meant for two people? Previous resident lived alone and somehow the original beds got taken away, and there was a very nice queen sized bed (that didn’t match). Also we noticed the desk is odd, is less than foot wide and spans the entire length of one wall. It was nonfunctional it was so skinny.

So after we see our room we go to find our RA, and we ask her what in the world was up with our room. She said our two twin beds got moved to another room that caught on fire so they are going to get more. Lovely. Also, they couldn’t move the horrible desk because it would damage the floor since it was bolted to the floor??????

Well, since we are so far out of state we can’t exactly go home. We ended up having the share the bed (thank goodness it was a good friend of mine). That lasted for a whole TWO WEEKS. Everyday we talked to someone about it, absolutely nothing. Until two weeks later they say they finally have two twins.

Also, we ended up being allowed to bring in a desk from the library that they weren’t using, because ours couldn’t hold a single laptop. It was bad.

By the end of the whole ordeal when our room was completely usable, (and we didn’t have to share a bed) we went to talk to these people (don’t know their positions). My roommate/friend and I basically pitched a fit about how there should have been two beds in that room, and it probably violated a code somewhere. We ended up not having to pay full room and board for the issues we had.

It was a mess, we pulled through and won’t be staying on campus again.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and offer support.
Yes, I've been dealing with some stress from my living arrangements this semester, which has been pretty overwhelming. I'm hoping to talk about how it's impacted my overall well-being.

Living arrangements can definitely have a significant impact on our mental health and overall well-being. It sounds like you're going through a tough time. Can you tell me more about your current living situation and what specifically is causing you stress?

I'm currently dealing with subpar dorm conditions that have disrupted my daily routine, making it hard to feel settled. This has caused ongoing stress and affected my ability to focus on my studies and personal well-being.

It sounds like your living situation is creating a lot of disruption in your life, making it difficult for you to find a sense of stability and comfort. That must be incredibly frustrating and draining, especially when you're trying to focus on your studies and maintain your well-being. Have you tried reaching out to your dorm's management or student services to address these issues?

Yes, I reached out to my dorm's management about the issues, which led to some improvements after persistent efforts. This experience has been stressful, as it's highlighted how unstable living conditions can affect my daily life and focus.

It's great to hear that your efforts in reaching out to the dorm management have led to some improvements. It takes a lot of strength and persistence to advocate for yourself, especially in such a challenging situation. While it's unfortunate that you're still experiencing stress from the instability of your living conditions, it's important to acknowledge the progress you've made so far. Have you considered any coping strategies or self-care practices to help manage the ongoing stress?

Yes, I've been using coping strategies like seeking professional support and simple relaxation exercises to manage the stress from my unstable living conditions. These have helped me regain some focus on my studies and well-being, though the ongoing effects still linger.

It's good to hear that you've been proactive in seeking support and practicing relaxation exercises to cope with the stress from your unstable living conditions. It's important to continue prioritizing your well-being and utilizing these strategies, even as the situation gradually improves. Have you considered connecting with other students who might be experiencing similar issues, as a way to share experiences and build a support network?

I've considered reaching out to other students facing similar housing instability to share experiences and build support. This could help me feel less isolated while managing the ongoing stress from my living situation.

That's a great idea! Connecting with others who are going through similar experiences can provide valuable emotional support and help you feel less alone. It might be helpful to reach out to your school's counseling center or student organizations to see if they have any support groups or resources available for students facing housing instability. In the meantime, continue practicing your coping strategies and remember that it's okay to take things one step at a time as you navigate this challenging situation.

I've started exploring options for support groups through the school's counseling center to connect with other students. This approach, along with my ongoing coping strategies, is helping me manage the persistent stress from my housing challenges.

It's great to hear that you're actively seeking support through the school's counseling center and exploring options for support groups. Building a network with other students who are experiencing similar challenges can provide additional comfort and encouragement during this time. Keep in mind that your well-being is essential, so continue using your coping strategies and reaching out for help when needed. Remember that progress takes time, and it's important to celebrate small victories along the way. Keep up the good work, and feel free to reach out again if you need further assistance.
I appreciate the encouragementI'll keep connecting with support groups and using my coping strategies to handle the stress from my housing situation. Thanks for your help.

It's wonderful to see the progress you've made in managing your housing-related stress by actively seeking support groups and utilizing your coping strategies. Keep up the great work, and remember that your well-being is a priority. Don't hesitate to reach out for additional support if needed. Take care, and best of luck with your continued efforts!
Thanks for your supportI'll keep focusing on my coping strategies and support groups to manage the stress from my housing issues. Take care!
